text: Good morning everyone! a newbie question, I need to search a text (MPS) file to find some key word to locate the section “RHS”; then check the next line to see if that line has the word “obj”. If there is, then remove that line and save the file. Since the file is large, e.g., 30 mb, what is the most efficient way to implement this task? Thanks!

elements.text: Good morning everyone! a newbie question, I need to search a text (MPS) file to find some key word to locate the section “RHS”; then check the next line to see if that line has the word “obj”. If there is, then remove that line and save the file. Since the file is large, e.g., 30 mb, what is the most efficient way to implement this task? Thanks!

text: Is the keyword guaranteed to be on one single line, and not split across two lines?

elements.text: Is the keyword guaranteed to be on one single line, and not split across two lines?

text: RHS the only word on that line, starting the section. Then the next line is the first row in this section with multiple words. I just need to see if the first line has “obj” and then remove that line.

elements.text: RHS the only word on that line, starting the section. Then the next line is the first row in this section with multiple words. I just need to see if the first line has “obj” and then remove that line.

text: Ah, that should be pretty easy then.

text: glad to hear

Something like
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    infile = open(inpath)
    outfile = open(outpath, "w")
    skip_next = false
    for line in eachline(file)
        if line == "RHS"
            skip_next = true
        else
            skip_next = false
            if skip_next
                continue
            end
        end
        println(outfile, line)
    end
end```

end

text: Then you can search for `obj` in the next line, and if you find it, print out the vector before that line, and after that line

text:
Does this work? DIdn't check it
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(read, inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj", s)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath) do writer
        write(@view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(@view data[last(range):end])
    end
end```

text: Thanks <@U7HAYKY9X> It will take me a while to understand the code.  I will try both of them and let you know the efficiency difference.

elements.text: It will take me a while to understand the code.  I will try both of them and let you know the efficiency difference.

text:
OK, tested it a bit. Try this:
```function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj[^\n]*\n", data)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath, "w") do writer
        write(writer, @view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(writer, @view data[last(range)+1:end])
    end
end```

elements.text: OK, tested it a bit. Try this:

function foo(inpath, outpath)
    data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath)
    range = findfirst(r"RHS\n[^\n]*obj[^\n]*\n", data)
    if range === nothing
        cp(inpath, outpath)
    end
    open(outpath, "w") do writer
        write(writer, @view data[1:first(range)+3])
        write(writer, @view data[last(range)+1:end])
    end
end

text: Ah, I think perhaps `@view`  for Strings were added in a recent version of Julia. If you use an older one, try using `SubString(data, a:b)` instead of `@view data[a:b]`

elements.text: for Strings were added in a recent version of Julia. If you use an older one, try using

text: The `r` in front of a string creates a Regex object. Are you familiar with Regex? It's like a mini-programming language for specifying patterns in strings, very useful for text processing

elements.text: in front of a string creates a Regex object. Are you familiar with Regex? It's like a mini-programming language for specifying patterns in strings, very useful for text processing

text: Regex is also used in other languages, I recommend reading about it on the internet. It's pretty neat even if the patterns can look confusing

text: Just one more newbie question <@U7HAYKY9X>, in your code data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath), i’m a bit confused: -> is supposed to assign a function to a variable; but then why io is in the function parameter?  I read open documentation, it has a similar example but I couldn’t understand.

elements.text: , in your code data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath), i’m a bit confused: -> is supposed to assign a function to a variable; but then why io is in the function parameter?  I read open documentation, it has a similar example but I couldn’t understand.

text:
It's also a little complicated. So if you have a function `f` , then `open(f, "my_file.txt")` opens `"my_file"` , applies the function `f` to the file, and closes it.
And `x -> y` is the syntax for an "anonymous function", that is, a shorthand way to write small functions (take `x` and return `y` ).

elements.text: It's also a little complicated. So if you have a function

to the file, and closes it.
And
is the syntax for an "anonymous function", that is, a shorthand way to write small functions (take

text:
So `data = open(io -> String(read(io)), inpath),` does the same as:
```foo(x) = String(read(x))
file = open(inpath)
data = foo(file)
close(file)```

elements.text:
foo(x) = String(read(x))
file = open(inpath)
data = foo(file)
close(file)

text: Thanks <@U7HAYKY9X>! After reading Anonymous Function documentation, this totally makes senses now.
